åˆ·æ–°å¸ƒå±€ï¼Œä¸ä¼šç«‹å³åˆ·æ–°
Call this method on your applicationâ€™s main thread when you want to adjust the layout of a viewâ€™s subviews. This method makes a note of the request and returns immediately. Because this method does not force an immediate update, but instead waits for the next update cycle, you can use it to invalidate the layout of multiple views before any of those views are updated. This behavior allows you to consolidate all of your layout updates to one update cycle, which is usually better for performance.

setNeedsLayout makes sure a future call to layoutIfNeeded calls layoutSubviews.

It is almost always cleaner and easier to update a constraint immediately after the affecting change has occurred. For example, if you want to change a constraint in response to a button tap, make that change directly in the buttonâ€™s action method.

Hot and Cold Observable
å®˜æ–¹ä»‹ç»
When does an Observable begin emitting its sequence of items? It depends on the Observable. A â€œhotâ€ Observable may begin emitting items as soon as it is created, and so any observer who later subscribes to that Observable may start observing the sequence somewhere in the middle. A â€œcoldâ€ Observable, on the other hand, waits until an observer subscribes to it before it begins to emit items, and so such an observer is guaranteed to see the whole sequence from the beginning.
